title: Lambda Velorum
text:
Lambda Velorum (λ Velorum, abbreviated Lambda Vel, λ Vel), officially named Suhail , is a <a href="star">star</a> in the <a href="Southern%20celestial%20hemisphere">southern</a> <a href="constellation">constellation</a> of <a href="Vela%20%28constellation%29">Vela</a>. With a mean <a href="apparent%20visual%20magnitude">apparent visual magnitude</a> of 2.21, this is the <a href="List%20of%20stars%20in%20Vela">third-brightest star in the constellation</a> and one of the <a href="List%20of%20brightest%20stars">brighter stars</a> in the sky. The distance to this star can be measured directly using the <a href="parallax">parallax</a> technique, yielding an estimated from the <a href="Sun">Sun</a>.
Nomenclature.
"λ Velorum" (<a href="Latinisation%20of%20names">Latinised</a> to "Lambda Velorum") is the star's <a href="Bayer%20designation">Bayer designation</a>.
It bore the traditional <a href="Arabic">Arabic</a> name السهيل الوزن "suhayl al-wazn" ("Al Suhail al Wazn"), but as a modern <a href="List%20of%20selected%20stars%20for%20navigation">navigation star</a> this was shortened to "Suhail". '<a href="Suhail">Suhail</a>' (a common Arabic male first name) was traditionally used for at least three other stars: <a href="Canopus">Canopus</a>; <a href="Gamma%20Velorum">Gamma Velorum</a> (al Suhail al Muhlif); and <a href="Zeta%20Puppis">Zeta Puppis</a> (Suhail Hadar). In 2016, the <a href="International%20Astronomical%20Union">International Astronomical Union</a> organized a <a href="Working%20Group%20on%20Star%20Names">Working Group on Star Names</a> (WGSN) to catalogue and standardize proper names for stars. The WGSN approved the name "Suhail" for this star on 21 August 2016 and it is now so entered in the IAU Catalog of Star Names ("Canopus" had its name approved as is, and Zeta Puppis was given the name "Naos").
In <a href="Chinese%20astronomy">Chinese astronomy</a>, Suhail is called 天記 (<a href="Pinyin">Pinyin</a>: Tiānjì), meaning "Judge for Estimating the Age of Animals", because this star is marking itself and stands alone in the "Judge for Estimating the Age of Animals" <a href="Asterism%20%28astronomy%29">asterism</a>. <a href="Ghost%20%28Chinese%20constellation%29">Ghost</a> mansion (see: <a href="Chinese%20constellation">Chinese constellation</a>), 天記 (Tiānjì), was westernized into "Tseen Ke", but the name "Tseen Ke" was designated for <a href="Psi%20Velorum">Psi Velorum</a> by R. H. Allen works and the meaning is "Heaven's Record".
Properties.
The outer envelope of λ Velorum has an <a href="effective%20temperature">effective temperature</a> of about , giving it the cool orange hue of a <a href="K-type%20star">K-type star</a>. It is an Lc-type, <a href="slow%20irregular%20variable">slow irregular</a> <a href="variable%20star">variable star</a> with its brightness varying between apparent magnitudes +2.14 to +2.30.
λ Velorum is an <a href="stellar%20evolution">evolved</a> star that has exhausted the hydrogen in its core region. It has about seven times the mass of the Sun. It is likely to be on or approaching the <a href="asymptotic%20giant%20branch">asymptotic giant branch</a> (AGB), although its properties do not exclude it being a slightly more massive star on the <a href="red%20giant%20branch">red giant branch</a> (RGB). As an AGB star it has an inert core of carbon and oxygen and is alternately fusing helium and hydrogen in two shells outside the core. The star's outer envelope has expanded to form a deep, <a href="convection%20zone">convective</a>, <a href="Hydrogen%20burning">hydrogen-burning</a> layer that is generating a <a href="stellar%20magnetic%20field">magnetic field</a>. The surface strength of this field has been measured at . Massive stars use their hydrogen "fuel" much faster than do smaller stars and Lambda Velorum is estimated to be only some 32 million years old.
λ Velorum is near the upper end of the mass range for intermediate stars, which end their lives by producing a <a href="planetary%20nebula">planetary nebula</a> and a <a href="white%20dwarf">white dwarf</a> remnant. It may be massive enough to produce an <a href="electron-capture">electron-capture</a> <a href="supernova">supernova</a>.
